word: We can have but faint conceptions of the inexpressible anguish of God's dear Son in Gesthsemane as he realized the separation from his Father in consequence of bearing man's sin. He became sin for the fallen race. The sense of the withdrawal of his Father's love pressed from his anguished soul these words: "My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death." "If it be possible, let this cup pass from me." Then with entire submission to his Father's will he adds, "Nevertheless, not as I will, but as thou wilt."
